case.title: The Riverside Park Disappearance
case.summary: Sarah Johnson, a 28-year-old nurse at Minneapolis General Hospital, vanished after her night shift. Her car was found three days later in Riverside Park, keys still in the ignition. No signs of struggle. Her purse was missing, but her jacket remained on the passenger seat.

evidence.description: Abandoned 1985 Honda Civic with keys in ignition
Male figure seen near vehicle at 11 PM
Recent breakup with hospital coworker Dr. Mark Stevens

visualCues.speaker: maya
visualCues.text: Welcome back to Cold Case Crawler. I'm Maya Vance, and today we're diving into a case that's haunted Minnesota investigators for decades.

visualCues.speaker: thorne
visualCues.text: And I'm Dr. Aris Thorne. The case Maya's referring to involves a disappearance with virtually no physical evidence - just witness testimony and circumstantial connections.

visualCues.speaker: maya
visualCues.text: But here's what's fascinating - the witness accounts don't just contradict each other, they create an impossible timeline. Someone saw our victim at 3 PM, another at 5 PM, but the last confirmed sighting was actually at 2:30.

visualCues.speaker: thorne
visualCues.text: That's precisely the problem with this case. Without corroborating evidence, we're left with unreliable human memory. Eyewitness testimony is notoriously unreliable, especially after decades.
visualCues.evidenceText: Witness Report: Male figure seen near vehicle at 11 PM

visualCues.speaker: maya
visualCues.text: Okay, but what about the pattern? This isn't the only disappearance in that area during that time period. Three people, all within a five-mile radius, all within six months.

visualCues.speaker: thorne
visualCues.text: Correlation isn't causation, Maya. Rural Minnesota in the 1980s - people moved away, changed their lives, started over. Not every missing person is a victim of foul play.

visualCues.speaker: maya
visualCues.text: But the families never heard from them again. No phone calls, no letters, no social media presence years later. That's not starting over - that's vanishing.
visualCues.evidenceText: Evidence: Abandoned 1985 Honda Civic with keys in ignition

visualCues.speaker: thorne
visualCues.text: I'll grant you that's unusual. But without physical evidence, without a crime scene, we're speculating. The data simply doesn't support a serial killer theory.

visualCues.speaker: maya
visualCues.text: Sometimes the absence of evidence IS the evidence, Dr. Thorne. Someone was very, very good at making people disappear without a trace.

visualCues.speaker: thorne
visualCues.text: And that's exactly the kind of thinking that leads investigations astray. We follow the evidence, not the narrative. Until we have concrete proof, this remains an unsolved missing persons case.
